subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Indeed, that is the central issue for any kind of writing or spelling reform for English-as-a-whole. ... That got taken out of context.  There are 8
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> If I'm not mistaken, the biggest problem facing us right now is what to
> do with mergers. I don't hear the difference between "beer" and "bear,"
> so how do I write this word? Do I write it as I hear it, but for more
> formal writing look up its *pronounciation* (not spelling!) in a
> standard dictionary? I think we have debated this issue quite a bit, and
> with good reason, considering it is our biggest obstacle. I'm open to
> any suggestions on how to deal with mergers.

Indeed, that is the central issue for any kind of writing or spelling
reform for English-as-a-whole.

> > > Since there are only eight lexical sets and 15 vowels, there will need
> > > to be some more or less arbitrary conventions to determine which vowel
> > > is used to write which set.
> >
> > This must be done with the utmost care:
>
> Sorry to be dense, but I don't follow. There are many more sets than
> 15--in fact, more than there are vowels.

That got taken out of context. There are 8 lexical sets *involving
/r/*, namely NURSE, NEAR, SQUARE, START, NORTH, FORCE, CURE, and LETTER.
That means that in a lexical-set based system we have to make choices
about which vowels to use before Roar and which not to. My proposal
is that NURSE and LETTER use Utter, NEAR uses Eat, SQUARE uses Ate,
START uses Ah, NORTH uses Awe, FORCE uses Owe, and CURE uses
(Ye-)Ooze, all before Roar.

> > But is this a significant improvement over Et+Key+See+Et+No+Tea for

If this is New Zealand phonetic, then the second Et should be It.
(Yes, Read's names suck.)

> > "accent". I'm not being glib, it is an important question: I want to
> > make sure we are not trading known problems for unknown ones.

Using the lexical sets disposes of vowel shifts like New Zealands:
TRAP is At for everybody. It doesn't dispose of mergers, and
it's a fact that some people merge CURE with NORTH/FORCE, which
means that instead of Ooze-R (or Foot-R, whichever we settle on),
they would tend to use Awe-R.

Once again the fundamental problem of mergers arises: do we
make people learn (or look up) an artificial unmerged pronunciation,
or do we let them write the merged words every which way?
In the case of the /r/ lexical sets, Read has decreed the use
of Roe, and I think he's right: but we rhotic-speakers musn't
underestimate the effort that will put on non-rhotics to
remember where to write Roe and where not to.
